Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Risk Perception, Threat, and Anxiety Decay in Lone-Wolf Terrorist Events in the US

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies risk perceptions among the American public regarding domestic terrorism, with a particular focus on so-called "lone-wolf" terrorist attacks. The study surveys a nationally representative sample of U.S. residents, then re-surveys them at a later time. This enables the investigators to study risk perceptions relating to domestic terrorism and, particularly, how those risk perceptions increase or decrease over time. The survey measures a number of characteristics associated with perceptions of various types of terrorism attacks, including so-called lone-wolf attacks. The second survey will measure the same characteristics approximately six months after the first survey. The combined data from the two surveys will contribute to a better understanding of the correlates of risk perceptions of terrorist events and how and why those perceptions change over time. Better understanding of the specific and potentially unique risk and threat perceptions associated with lone-wolf terrorist attacks has implications for public policy and institutional responses.

More specifically, the project will employ a two-wave panel survey of risk perceptions relating to domestic terrorism among a nationally representative sample of U.S. residents. This two-wave design will enable the investigators to test theoretically and practically important hypotheses about the dynamics of perceptions of risk in lone-wolf attacks, how these perceptions change over a 6-month period of time, including the character of perceived risk "decay" and "social amplification," and how these changes compare with risk perceptions of other kinds of threat. The investigators hope to get the first wave into the field in as close time proximity as possible to the focusing events of 2015 in San Bernardino (December 2), Colorado Springs (November 17), Paris (November 13), Chattanooga (July 16), and Charleston (June 17). Wave 1 of the survey measures perceptions of various types of terrorism attacks, including an effort to identify which of a number of events respondents consider to be lone-wolf attacks. The questionnaire will be administered over the internet to a nationally representative sample. The wave 1 sample will consist of approximately 1,700 respondents. The wave 2 survey will consist of re-interviews of an estimated 1,200 of these 1,700 respondents 6 months after the initial interviews The difference in number of respondents is due to expected attrition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigates public perceptions of risk and threat for two types of domestic terrorism – those committed by terrorist organizations and those committed by lone-wolfs. Current knowledge of risk and threat perceptions for terrorist attacks is rooted in large-scale coordinated terrorist acts, especially the 9/11 attacks. Project results will help inform current understandings of terrorist risk and threat perceptions as well as suggest changes to policies for counteracting lone-wolf terror attacks. For this study, lone wolfs are individuals who act on their own, perhaps inspired by external organizations but without coordination with such organizations.

The researchers use a two-wave panel survey to test hypotheses about risk perceptions and changes in these perceptions over time. The first wave measured risk characteristics associated with various types of terrorist attacks. The second wave measured these same characteristics six months later. Wave 1 included 7 violent attacks; Wave 2, these same attacks plus, another 5 that occurred after Wave 1. Most previous studies included only one focusing event. This panel survey enables analysis of risk perception dynamics that cannot be examined as well in any other way. The occurrence of additional attacks allows examining how these attacks, in general and based on additional characteristics such as type (mass shooting, vehicle, explosive), location (domestic or foreign), and perpetrator (race/ethnicity, religion) have contributed to either an amplification or decay of risk perceptions.

Moreover, this study enables comparison of lone-wolf terrorism attacks to foreign organized attacks to determine whether the lone-wolf type of attack carries a different risk perception profile. The two waves of this survey collected the same sort of data about lone-wolf terrorism attacks involving assault or improvised weapons and about terrorist attacks involving conventional and nuclear bombs, planes, and water supply poisoning. By analyzing the similarities and differences in risk and threat perceptions for both types of attacks, the researchers address important theoretical and practical gaps in the literature.

This study also permits investigation of recollection bias with data that has never been available before. Recollection bias is the phenomena by which people report that their perceived level of risk associated with a threat (such as, say, the 9/11 events) is the same or lower after the occurrence of that event than it was before the event even though it seems more appropriate for people’s perceived risk to be higher. Wave 1 collected data about the perceived risk of various types of attacks. Between the two survey waves, an attack occurred that matches one of the types of attacks included in the Wave 1. So data gathered during Wave 2 includes respondents’ recollections of their perceived risks associated with this type of attack during Wave 1. Thus, the researchers can compare the accuracy of respondents’ recollections of their risk to their previously reported risk levels. Other studies only collected people’s recollection of perceived risk post event.

The Wave 1 sample (May 5-17, 2016), drawn from a web-enabled probability-based panel designed to be representative of the adult U.S. population, resulted in 1,730 completed surveys. Wave 2 (November 10 -17, 2016), sampled only those who participated in Wave 1, yielding 1,210 completed surveys.

With data analysis ongoing, the researchers have found the following results so far:

1. Perceived risk of terrorism is predicted by the psychometric variables of perceived severity, perceived number of people affected, and perceived likelihood of attack, and by the demographic variables of gender and education.

2. Higher risk perception and higher ascriptions of government competence lead to stronger support for counterterrorism spending. 

3. There is no significant decay between the two waves in overall risk perception level or spending preference. Changes in an individual's risk perception are positively associated with changes in psychometric variables; changes in spending preference are predicted by changes in perceived risk and changes in perceived government competence.  

4. There is overwhelming support that one's perception of institutional competence is related to approval for spending and other policy strategies for reducing terrorist events in the US.

5. Females, minorities, those with lower household incomes, married people, political conservatives, and individuals with less formal education are more likely to experience feelings of decreased personal safety and more likely to alter behavior following lone-wolf terrorist attacks.

6. Strong evidence supports the general occurrence of recollection bias and its persistence across various forms of terrorism risk. Females, older people, political conservatives, and Republicans are less likely to exhibit recollection bias. Income has no significant effect.

7. Recollection bias significantly reduces support for a wide range of preventive policy measures and government spending on antiterrorism efforts.

8. Preliminary results suggest that the nationalistic and xenophobic rhetoric of the 2016 presidential campaing influenced people to be more likely to characterize attacks perpetrated by whites as non-terror, lone-wolf events, and those perpetrated by Muslims as terrorist attacks that were coordinated with others.
